meta.description:
We have entered a sometimes-unconfortable weird duality where we want an extremely personalized experience everywhere but also tend to reject any prying attempts to learn patterns of ours.
It is now up to companies and institutions to invest in two complementary and necessary venues: transparency so that the person never feels they're being misled and privacy protection methods and structures.
Not every entity has the magnitude of Facebook to withstand the loss of trust and finantial hit breach after breach.

With the slew of machine learning and AI implementations to monitor behavior and find patterns in everything, the field of personalization has never been more fertile - and people will embrace it.
The crucial factor here is to find the right balance between customer data and driving convenience - customer loyalty will reside in the entity that can meet that one consumer's demands to a T.

Customer experience has a 24/7 frequency, nowadays. Through chat platforms such as Whatsapp or Instagram Direct, people can easily get in touch with anyone, anywhere, and they want instant answers to any query. �If you can take my money 24 hours a day, you should be available to answer my questions, too.�

While the sharing economy was mostly accelerated in mobility and real estate rental, its consequences are being felt universally. This is one of the big drivers in the rise of platform organizations.
The regular user is - of course - relatively agnostic to how a service operates. The consensual shift to platforms supported by sharing economy models is explained by the sheer scalability and seamlessness that are now within reach.
To businesses operating with their core parallel to these players, it is urgent that they form partnerships, because the advantages in speed, efficiency and ease of maintenance/cost to run seem unrivalled and piling up.

Part of a greater whole, transparency has never been as present in people's minds as today. Besides paying attention to the supply chain footprint of the food we buy, society is increasingly privileging options in every field that operate in a glassdoor manner. Clothes coming from Southeast Asia resonate with humans rights violations. Users are glad to know that Apple is promising to use 100% recycled Aluminum and stride to recycle 100% in their own and (already billions) other iPhones sold.

Technology adoption among is universally attributed to Millenials and younger generations. This is partly true, but leads to a gross underestimation of tech use in older generations. Especially older urban dwellers are more than happy to adopt smart locks for safety, kitchen assistants for convenient cooking and uber to stop waiting for a taxi while it's raining.
This proves to be a greatly misrepresented segment that embodies a great business oportunity, if only companies start planning around it (remember older generations also have greater purchasing power).

There�s an increasing saturation over the massification of artificially fabricated lifestyles projected by TV, Facebook, and Instagram accounts. People are craving for authenticity and real-human connections.

Having an active interest in one's health. Be health consciousness implies to know what good health is and what are healthy and unhealthy practices; to monitor health condition like body weight, sleep control, sight and hearing test, mental checkups; to avoid practices that adversely affect one�s health; to take corrective actions whenever your health is not within acceptable norms.

Technology has finally matured enough for customers to start trusting it to avoid some of the most inefficient parts of their shopping experience. Machine learning is helping people to complete their shopping list while artificial vision is enabling the skipping of those never-ending checkout lines. Many other applications are being implemented to optimize people�s time and maximize their life quality.

The massification of online courses reflects the increasing effort that is needed nowadays to keep up with technology advancements. Knowledge is more accessible then ever, but also more volatile. Learning is a continuous process and people are looking for the right tools to keep on board of the train to the future.

Collected from renewable sources such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves and geothermal heat, renewable energy is charging the future. �It is expected that by 2040 the production of renewable electricity will be able to guarantee, in a cost-effective way, the total annual electricity consumption of mainland Portugal� advanced the Portuguese Renewable Energy Association as in March 2018, renewable energy generated 104% of Portugal�s electricity consumption. According to the same source, this successful event demonstrated that �renewable energy can be relied upon as a secure and viable source with which to completely meet the country�s electricity demands�. Some of the biggest companies in the world, including Apple, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft, are massively buying renewable energy and, consequently, reshaping the entire supply chain. �The IT sector has been responsible for more than 7GW of new renewable energy globally � enough to power 5m homes� says Gary Cook, Greenpeace�s senior corporate campaigner.

Without touching the discussion topic to what caused this movement, it is unquestionably that there is a fast-rising concern for how "gut-friendly" the food we buy really is. Fashionable expressions such as pro or prebiotics are dealbreakers in the daily choices made by a growingly significant segment of society. To the unaware, the myriad of intolerances we hear about seems to have sprung from nowhere, but it certainly drove an unforeseen demand for the likes of tempeh, kefir, kimchi, flaxseed, and anything else that helps the consumer to steer clear from the wide selection of ingredients they've found harmful (think gluten, sat, unsat or trans fat, lactose, etc...).

Less than a quarter of the food that is wasted in the US, UK and Europe could feed the one billion hungry people all around the world. With an estimation of 1.3 billion tonnes of food being wasted every year, people are looking for this topic with particular concern and expect the companies where they spend their money to tackle this issue.

Total foreign residency in Portugal has been steadily rising for a few years, to a point where a significant demographic segment has different primary languages and cultures. If the current political climate remains relatively stable, this is only expected to accelerate.
With today's advances in personalization, behavior analysis and related tools, great oportunities lie in adjusting supply to a changing customer base.

Today's means of acquiring knowledge in any topic is widely different from a few years ago. Content creation in the web today has reached a granularity that allows for whomever, with whichever skillbase to quickly find informative content from the most practical topics such as "How to: fry, bake, poach and scramble eggs" to the most complex and abstract subjects in Advanced Mathematics or Quantum Mechanics.
While true volume exists mostly in english, with instant contextual translation making strides, it is all quickly being democratized to all.
This trend is being felt at the corporate level too, with Google, Apple and other powerhouses announcing that academic degrees are no longer weighted the way they were.
Companies should much rather employ someone who can quickly and effectively learn skill X when current standard Y turns obsolete than a proven expert in Y.

People will compare players, even from different industries, using the same criteria. Customers are indifferent to cost structure: if a store offers free bags, they'll expect the same treat from every other store. To stay competitive, companies should be able to optimize their cost structure and establish what's essential to provide what the customers are expecting. To do so, they must understand that people's expectations can come from the least expectable places.

names: Fluid Expectations in Placemaking: Four Trends and Strategies

meta.description: It is no secret that the portuguese demographic pyramid is getting dangerously top-heavy. What may be changing, at least in the professional market, is what companies can use to face this threat. Companies should brace for a powerful hit in the form of retirement benefits and healthcare as baby boomers maintain leadership and it simultaneously becomes harder to attract (and maintain) young talent. The uberization of every field is one way this is being tackled (or rather, circumvented), but awareness (and investment along with it) needs to increase for companies to find creative ways of facing this looming threat.

Over the last few years, society has embraced connected devices and progressively divorced traditional linear content services. Over-the-top (OTT) video from players such as Netflix, Amazon Fire TV, Apple TV or Roku had a delayed start in the Portuguese market, as is usual, but this makes it all the more relevant for side business to rethink their content design and marketing. Advertisers today have a blank canvas full of opportunities to connect with consumers in a previously impossibly organic, personalized manner.

According to ConvenienceStore, �the increase in shoppers looking for meals �for the next three days� is growing with 55% of shoppers claiming to visit a convenience store for a top-up mission, 11% for a meal prep mission and 17% for food-to-go�.
As the shopping experience keeps getting more convenient, people tend to privilege smaller baskets and increase the frequency of their visits to the store. Retailers are accompanying this trend by reducing store�s dimensions, while optimizing their cost per square meter.

A social trend that has closely followed the technological advances in interfacing, it is shifting the paradigm of how we connect with machines. There is a reason babies today can outperform their parents on a tablet at the age of 2 (imagine doing that with MS-DOS in the 80s) and there will also be consequences.
For one, there will be zero tolerance for unintuitive UI, users will simply move to one of your 100 competitors for a better experience. We need to build for any human to use, with bonus points if the interface is adaptive to the individual user.

names:
Intelligent interfaces -
Reimagining the way humans

meta.description: Reviews, good pictures and nice displays are not enough anymore. The biggest friction in eCommerce is the fact that, before buying a product, people still want to feel its touch, taste or smell. And whoever's capable of providing that will get the upper hand over those who can't.

According to BBC, 400 million tons of plastic is produced every year with 40% of its applications being thrown out after the first use. Plastic is not biodegradable, which means it will stay around for hundreds of years � representing a big threat for the environment. 
The debate on reducing plastic production is gathering more followers every day and people expect retailers to be a part of the process to save the world. Sustainable materials for packaging and bulk food are some of the solutions that customers value and are willing to pay extra to get.

Consumers are shifting their attention from TV to Youtube, Facebook and Instagram. Social media influencers are the new epicenter of new lifestyles, behaviors and social trends. This represents an opportunity for retailers to promote their products in a more decentralized (and effective) way. Companies who provide digital sharable products and experiences increase their reach with continuously growing scalability.

A single family will probably have numerous diet restrictions: grandma is lactose intolerant, the father is gluten--free and the older daughter is trying a vegan regimen. The criteria of this family�s shopping list is almost impossible to meet � and that�s why they�ll prefer the retailer who provides them a customized service that addresses all their needs. By reducing the amount of plastic needed for packaging, bulk food is a win-win situation to the customer, the retailer, and the planet.

Consumers want to know the story of the product. A study conducted by Origin/Hill Holiday found that people are willing to pay more for a product that's accompanied by a narrative - its perceived value will increase if it's followed by the producer�s story, another user's review or any other type of content that helps people relating to that particular item or service.

Consumer's attention span has been abruptly decreasing for the past few years. If a brand can't communicate its messages or value propositions in the first seconds of the conversation, people will look for something else. Customers expect to be immediately served and will have no mercy for the runner up in the delivery race. Whoever's serves first, serves better.

FOMO defines the fear of not getting in on a deal, experience, event or other activity, strongly correlated with social pressure. It is not exactly recent/emergent, but is today increasingly relevant, and is most prevalent among millenials and younger generations, in/entering prime spending age.
Marketing tends to overuse this concept to motivate consumers to do last-minute purchasing decisions. This has to be done with care, as it risks frustrating loyal customers who will then be tired of having their hand forced.
The number of offices with a desk rotation policy is increasing everywhere. Workers are valuing the convenience that flexible work stations represent, as well as the freedom to work from home.

Too much choice can be as harmful as no choice at all: just think of the time you spend trying to choose what to watch on Netflix. AI and Data mining are helping customers making some sense of the chaos with shopping list recommendations or customized campaigns.

Schizophrenic (or non-linear) consumption portrays the fact that some consumers are willing to spend less money on some purchases so that they can dive into some other indulgences (e.g. exclusively buying white brand food to save for an iPhone). This behavior can be fostered by financial savviness or can simply be arbitrary.

The number of people with particular diets is increasing and food retailers must adapt. People want a customized service for every situation (e.g. 2 people in a couple buying 2 different meals and still eating together)
People, particularly millennials, are increasingly looking for careers with a purpose and avoiding jobs with meaningless repetitive tasks.
The fight against animal cruelty keeps gathering new supporters and some paradigms such as bullfighting and slaughterhouses may have their days counted.

Virtual assistants can provide quick information to customers, employees or partners on the go. These assistants can be available to remote users through smartphones, smart speakers, or smart appliances. Presential users can access these assistants through kiosks. Chatbots can provide quick information to customers, employees or partners on the go. Can be made available through dedicated messaging APPs like WhatsAPP or embedded in existing channels like the on-line stores or APPs.

implementation.name: Automation and Artificial Intelligence: How machines are affecting people and places
implementation.author: jgp

meta.description:
With robots and automation making more and more frequent appearances in our everyday lives, we, people, are confronted with the progressive decrease in human interaction. Despite this, at our core, we are social animals, and we like being with other people (whether we like it or not, ah!). A collateral consequence that arises is that people give authenticity and humanity higher value. Federico Marchetti said it beautifully when he predicted that "in the future there will be one label that will convey [a sense quality] to the customers - 'Made by Humans'".
Making the right choices when it comes to automation isn't always limited to efficiency and cost. Allowing the human touch to permeate your products and services where it matters most, can be a powerful loyalty driver, justifying and even contradicting RPAs or seamlessness.

Currently, voice control is, with little doubt, the closest we have to achieving the fluidity necessary for this - we certainly must teach someone what "Ctrl+A" is, and does anything interesting, but shouting "Hey Siri, play me the Beatles" comes second to language (and some good taste...).

Addressing the need to belong is the oldest commercial trick in the book. People want to be a part of something and brands must be able to address that social requirement. The good news is that the digital transformation that we're living in is boosting the businesses' ability to do it.

The digital age is skyrocketing the (peer) pressure through the roof, which, for retailers, represents both an opportunity (the feeling of emergency and the fear of missing out are sales drivers) and a threat (people's increasing desire to disconnect and to subscribe to digital detox programs or lifestyles).

partner.description: Enjoy healthy, low fat vegetarian versions of your favourite recipes. Browse products & learn about our mission to produce healthy protein for a healthy planet.

partner.name: Cuisine Soleil
partner.author: jgp
partner.description: Healty and made with our productsOver 2000 retailers across CanadaDiscover products and recipes

partner.name: Algama
partner.author: jgp
partner.description: Algama creates the next-generation daily food product that harnesses the unique potential of microalgae with a tasty spoonful of joy: good for people and sustainable.

partner.name: kriket
partner.author: jgp
partner.description: KRIKET is a delicious snack. An irresistible mix of nuts, grains, seeds and crickets, and 100% sourced in Brussels.

partner.name: Seamore
partner.author: jgp
partner.description: We believe we have found something that will change the way we think of food. Upgrade your food with I sea bacon and I sea pasta.

partner.name: Sens
partner.author: jgp
partner.description: The most innovative bars with crickets, the new superfood. Pure ingredients only, no added sugar, gluten free and delicious.

partner.name: Memphis Meats
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: The company's process includes isolating small amounts of animal cells that are able to regenerate, and providing them with oxygen and nutrients, with fetal bovine serum used in order to initiate the entire process. The cells can then be harvested anywhere between nine to 21 days. The process uses 90% less water and land, and 50% less energy compared to conventional agriculture.

partner.name: SuperMeat
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Cultured meat is made from animal cells, without the use of the animals themselves. The final outcome is an all purpose meat. The production of cultured meat begins by incubating cells in a media that is rich in nutrients. Those nutrients help the cells thrive and divide. It is biologically the same as the meat that comes from animals. Our products will be non GMO and with no animal products besides the original cells.

partner.name: Impossible foods
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: A vegetarian burger that looks just like meat because it contains heme which contains iron which, when exposed to oxygen, turns red, just like blood, and also creates those meat flavors. Heme is a protein that can both be found in blood and in the roots of some leguminosae which are nitrogen-fixing plants such as soy and alfalfa.

partner.name: Gold&Green Foods
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Gold&Green Foods calls their version "pulled oats" since it is made from oats and broad beans from Finland and Sweden. The product is created by having the oats "sheared and heated under the right conditions and combined with the beans," and the flavor options include nude, kaffir lime with sesame and ginger, and tomato with smoked pepper and cilantro.

partner.name: Beyond burger
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Beyond Meat® products are 100% plant protein. Beyond Beef is 100% pea protein and Beyond Chicken is a blend of soy and pea protein.  The Beyond Burger looks, cooks, and tastes like a fresh beef burger.

partner.name: AHIMI
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Ahimi™ is a healthy, safe, raw Ahi without the tuna. Made from tomatoes and a few simple ingredients, this clean cuisine offers all the taste without harming our oceans. Tomatoes contain high levels of naturally-occurring glutamic acids, which are responsible for the savory flavor of meaty foods.

partner.name: Vbites
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: The only truly sustainably sourced salmon. Our plant-based salmon alternative can be used for a variety of foodstuffs. Create canapes as a party food. Try a few slices in a bagel with a vegan cream cheese. Throw strips into a scrambled tofu. How you use this fantastic food is up to your imagination, but it’s always guaranteed to be delicious.

partner.name: Gardein - Golden Fishless Filet
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Gardein™ claim to help the world eat less meat. That's why we make delicious meatless chick'n tenders, meatless meatballs, and more. Now you can skip meat for a meal, or a month, without skipping your favorite foods.

partner.name: Perfect Day
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Based in Berkeley, California, Perfect Day is a startup that uses cellular agriculture to produce animal-free dairy proteins. By designing yeast to produce the same dairy proteins found in milk from a cow, Perfect Day can make the same milk. Without needing the cow.

partner.name: Vegan Cheese
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Through synthetic biology yeasts are engineered to become milk-protein factories. Milk proteins are then combined with water and vegan oil to make vegan milk which is ultimately converted into vegan cheese.

partner.name: Ripple Original
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Ripple Original trade in thin, chalky nut milks for a plant-based alternative that’s actually rich, creamy and satisfying, with 8 times more protein than milk. Ripple Original is gentle on your body and the planet - 100% dairy-free, vegan, nut, lactose and gluten-free. Each serving has 8g of protein, 50% more calcium than 2% dairy milk, more Vitamin D and Iron and contains only ½ the sugar of 2% dairy milk.

partner.name: Good Karma Flaxmilk
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Sawyer features a 7 degree of freedom robot arm with a 1260 mm reach that maneuvers into tight spaces and operates in work cells designed for humans. Built-in force sensing capabilities allow it to make adaptive decisions as tasks run, enabling Sawyer to work precisely (+/- .1 mm), while operating safely next to people.

partner.name: Field Roast’s Chao Creamery
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Chao is a culinary tradition of fermenting tofu popular throughout Asia. Touted as the “cheese” of Asia, it can now easily be purchased in Asian grocery stores throughout North America and Europe. It looks much like marinated feta, as it is sold brined in a small jar, and has the mouthfeel of something like blue cheese.

partner.name: Daiya
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Daiya makes dairy-free food products. From grilled cheese to the rich and creamy taste of fruit-kissed yogurt. Every Daiya product — from macaroni and cheese to Greek yogurt alternative — is a plant-based, dairy-free alternative disguised as creamy, cheesy deliciousness right there on your plate. They are ready for lactose intolerant people, food allergies free, vegan and vegetarian.

partner.name: The Not Company
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Based on artificial intelligence, it looks for food formulas recurring only to vegetable sources, trying to mimic either the flavour or the texture of the original mayo.

partner.name: Follow you Heart - VeganEgg
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: A 100% plant-based egg, no gmo, no dairy, no gluten, no cholesterol.

partner.name: Aquafaba
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Egg’s white is replaced by the water that surrounds either chickpeas or white beans.

partner.name: Follow you Heart - Vegenaise
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: This breakthrough formula gives you a creamy and authentic cheese flavor dairy free and cholesterol free. This alternative is lactose free, soy free, gluten free, Non-GMO Project verified and contains no preservatives or trans fats.

partner.name: Bugsolutely
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Cricket pasta (20% bug, 80% flour). Crickets are actually very similar anatomically to shrimps, and they have fantastic food properties.

partner.name: EntoCube
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: EntoCube currently has the ability to produce controlled atmosphere shipping containers of various sizes that can be manually operated to farm food-grade insects.

technology.name: Cell growth for Meat substitutes
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Products made of muscle cells that never been inside of an animal - same taste, nutrient and texture as meat. It is a form of cellular agriculture. Cultured meat is produced using many of the same tissue engineering techniques traditionally used in regenerative medicine. Through this technique muscle tissue is produced, having this way cultured meat.

technology.name: Vegetable protein isolation for Meat substitutes
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Have vegetable based produtcs with the same nutrients set and taste  as meat or fish. Soy protein is globular while actual meat protein is fibrous, so food manufacturers alter the soy's molecular structure. This is typically done by exposing the soy protein to heat, acid or a solvent and then running the mixture through a food extruder that reshapes it. But soy isn't the only way to create meat-like products.
technology.prevwork: A internal project, Food Lab, is exploring readymade alternatives for hamburgers with Food Private Labels and H&W department.

technology.name: Non-animal protein isolation for Milk free dairy
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Have vegetable or yeast based products with the same taste and nutrients set as animal based dairy products. The dairy industry is responsible for thousands of products, replacing milk is done recurring to vegetable sources and treating them to resemble the originals in either shape, texture, cooking behaviour or flavour. Most dairy-free substitutes are made with yeast, soy protein, textured vegetable protein (TVP) or nuts oils

technology.name: Vegetable protein isolation for Egg substitutes
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Eggs can have a substitute themselves or be used for it’s broad features. A lot of products and recipes use eggs, and therefore there is a need to replace egg’s binding function, texture addition, or nutrient enrichment with vegetable sources.

technology.name: Insects for New foods
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: New foods are being developed to respond to consumer demand  . Edible insects contain high quality protein, vitamins and amino acids for humans. Insects have a high food conversion rate, needing less feed than animals to produce the same amount of protein.
technology.prevwork: A internal project, Food Lab, is exploring readymade alternatives for pasta and snacks with Food Private Labels and H&W department. DGAV denied to the request to commercialize insects.An internal project, Food Lab, is exploring readymade alternatives for pasta and snacks with Food Private Labels and H&W department. DGAV denied to the request to commercialize human food with insects. Further lobby must be done to go further with this project.

meta.description: Coming partly as a response to consumers' loss of confidence in the corporate world, the glassbox model is the most honest and radical stance relative to transparency and accountability - the companies adopting this model tend to openly disclose company policy (e.g. hiring practices, salary) and veer towards open-source development. When faced with a complication that could turn into a scandal/outrage, these agents announce that fact along with efforts being made to correct the wrong, instead of trying to quietly resolve the matter before it is discovered.

partner.name: Koalo
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Koalo create ecosystems to grow organic food indoors. Koaloponics combines leading-edge aquaponics research with web-connected tags, sensors and controls to create a smart indoor growing system.

partner.name: Firefly Dx real-time PCR pathogen detection system
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: The Firefly Dx real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) pathogen detection system is designed to provide real-time results in a handheld device, cutting out existing systems, which require lab-based equipment and can take hours/days to provide results. It is possible to detect E.coli bacteria in less than 20 minutes.

partner.name: C2Sense
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: C2Sense’s solution lies in developing sensors that can monitor volatiles directly related to meat/poultry/fish freshness and fruit ripeness at all stages of the supply chain. It is a result from MIT R&D.

partner.name: INL - Nano4Food
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Nano4Food is a R&D Unit working in Nanoencapsulation technologies to food functional properties, packaging solutions to extend shelf life , personalized and printable food, and  integrated lab-on-a-chip solutions for food quality, safety and, authenticity purposes.

partner.name: FRCFT
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: UCD Food Refrigeration & Computerised Food Technology (FRCFT) is an internationally recognized centre of excellence for food engineering research and education. FRCFT developed an hyperspectral imaging non-destructive method applied to food (e.g. meat, fruits, vegetables, fish) for sample classification and grading, defect and disease detection, distribution visualization of chemical attributes in chemical images, and evaluations of overall quality.

partner.name: Iris Monitoring
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Iris monitoring combines IR Spectroscopy and Machine Learning to deliver a set of solution for food and beverage analysis.

partner.name: Sintef
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: SINTEF (Norway) developed three innovative sensor systems to measure tenderness, water bonding and activity, bacterial contamination, and the detection of foreign bodies in meat products.

partner.name: Tellspec
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: Tellspec Food Sensor is able to scan food at a molecular level, identify calories, macronutrients, allergens, and also provide relevant information such as food fraud, food adulteration and food quality.

partner.name: Electronic Tongue
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: The electronic tongue is an innovative technology that can taste food through sensor.  Researchers at Porto University developed a nanosensor that can mimic what happens in our mouth when drinking wine.

partner.name: farm(x)
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: FarmX sensors measure soil, plant and environmental variables to accurately measure water stress. Advanced predictive algorithms deliver real-time irrigation actions.

partner.name: WiseCrop
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: WiseCrop collect the data needed for informed decision-making. Agricultural intelligence supports the decisions. It avoids unnecessary trips, allows to react immediately and allows efficient management of the business.

partner.name: Agroop

partner.name: Big Eye

partner.name: arc-net
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: arc-net connects every step of your product's journey to deliver supply chain transparency and product security. The arc-net toolset provides an easy to use scalable platform, powering the strategic insights that unlock profit .

partner.name: FoodLogiQ
partner.author: man
partner.description: A food industry software solution that specializes in Supplier Management, Food Safety Compliance, Quality Incident Management, Recall Management, and Whole Chain Traceability.

technology.name: Hydroponics for In-store greenhouse
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: In-store hydroponics to deliver the freshers products. Plants grow in an aquatic based environment where the nutrients are distributed through capillary action, without the use of soil.
technology.prevwork: A Study is available. An experiement was planned but it was canceled for lack of suitable partners for the envisaged use case.

technology.name: Aquaponics for In-store greenhouse
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: In-store production of greens and fish in a symbiotic environment. A symbiotic system where fishes and plants grow in a symbiotic way. The fishes share the water tank with bacteria that turn the fish waste into a rich fertilizer that is then fed to the plants.

technology.name: Sensors for Food quality analysis
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Specific low cost sensors can analyse the quality of food outside labs. Innovative technologies are being developed to analyse, in shelf, the overall quality of food, including their grade of maturation (in the case of fruit), the precise molecular composition, the presence of contaminants, and others.
technology.prevwork: Some devices were experimented in the past but none presented reliable results. Further study must ne done.

technology.name: Internet of things for Smart farming
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: IoT smart farming strategies can be applied to optimize food production and provide traceability. Through smart farming it is possible to increase both the quantity and the quality of agricultural products, as wells as the intelligence of farms. Collecting massive amounts of information, from soil mapping, crop fields, weather data and more, using specialized sensors will help in having a better productivity.

technology.name: Augmented reality for Extended product information
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Customers point their camera to items to obtain relevant product information shown in virtual objects. Additional information of a product is diplayed by pointing the camera, and the details about the product appear on screen, giving information that isn't on the label.

technology.name: E-paper for Electronic shelf labels
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Replace paper by e-paper based labels to save staff time, improve info accuracy, and agilize to princing politics. To create images, the display uses e-paper technology. With this tech the images are shown through e-ink, where a group of microcapsules contains tiny black or white spheres that are positioned according to the eletric charge given.

technology.name: Blockchain for Food traceability
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Track the origin and process chain of food ingredients to transparently deliver this info to customers. It's a decentralized technology that ensures data integrity adding a cryptography-based signature. When traceability data is added to a blockchain data base, it cannot be repudiated and adulterated by unauthorized entities.

technology.name: Printed electronics for Disposable smart labels
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Labels with embed sensors and/or displays can help to audit the supply chain. Electrochromic displays are printable on plastic or paper to produce smart labels. These displays use almost no power (no recharging or battery replacement). They are low weight, thin, flexible, transparent, yet robust. Can be combined with sensors (e.g. movement, temperature).
technology.prevwork: A study is available. An experiment to trace the temperature of meat supply chain is being envisaged.

meta.description: Information by request is already a reality in a selection of fields. Food past and characteristics seem like a logical next step that may align with the crescendo of worries about the environment and a fairer world.

technology.name: Smart materials for Self-heating packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Ready to eat food can deliver aditional convenience if the package can heat the food. The source of the heat for the self-heated packaging is an exothermic reaction initiated by the user. A container for the beverage surrounds a container of the heating agent separated from a container of water by a thin breakable membrane.
technology.prevwork: A study is available. We are currently looking for a viable partner to run a proof-of-concept

technology.name: Edible or water soluble films for Food packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Food packed in edible packaging to deliver optimum dosing, customer convenience and sustainability. Edible or water soluble plastic film is made from the milk protein casein which guards food against oxygen, and provide more sustainable products. Transparent, odorless and tasteless pre-portioned packets streamline food and beverage manufacturing, reducing cross-contamination and dusting in kitchen or manufacturing applications. Deliver ingredients such as various food coloring, spices and oils in food-grade water-soluble film.
technology.prevwork: A study was started in the end of 2018 to explore the possibility of using this material in bags for groceries or dry products sold in bulk (e.g. fruits and vegetables).

technology.name: Smart materials for Self-cooling packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Active packaging with the ability to cool down food contents without external power sources. Cooling is achieved by an endothermic reaction that the user initiates by pressing on the bottom of the can.  A container for the beverage surrounds a container of the cooling agent separated from a container of water by a thin breakable membrane. The resulting reaction consumes heat and thus colds the product surrounding it.
technology.prevwork: A study is available. We are currently looking for a viable partner to run a proof-of-concept

meta.description: One of the most significant parts contributing to Privacy Protection as a whole, is the preventive avoidance of data leaks, attacks, phishing, fraud, etc... This is the first line of defense, and it should go without saying that consumers only rest assured when they trust this is taken care of. Besides, although it is hard to measure return on investment for prevention, it is certainly cheaper than the PR crises and loss of trust that happens when it fails. Every company today should stop and think if they are prioritizing encryption, VPS usage when relevant, collecting only needed data, and the myriad of other good practices that so many neglect in place of cost reduction or marketing stunts.

technology.name: Blockchain for Financial services
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Blockchain promises to revolutionise transactions on the internet, by avoiding intermediaries. A distributed database maintains a list of data blocks secured from tampering and revision. Each block holds batches of individual transactions, timestamp and a link to a previous block. When a block is created, a copy is distributed across many systems. No centralized "official" copy exists and no user is "trusted" more than others.

meta.description: An equally important side to transparency is how a brand or company behaves in case of data compromise or any abnormal case of attack. partner.name: Solubags

This hydrosoluble material has no odor and is not toxic, and is resistant to grease, oils, and solvents. PVOH is ductile but strong, flexible, and functions as a high oxygen and aroma barrier.

partner.name: Tencel

technology.name: Edible or water soluble films for Food packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Food packed in edible packaging to deliver optimum dosing, customer convenience and sustainability. Edible or water soluble plastic film is made from the milk protein casein which guards food against oxygen, and provide more sustainable products. Transparent, odorless and tasteless pre-portioned packets streamline food and beverage manufacturing, reducing cross-contamination and dusting in kitchen or manufacturing applications. Deliver ingredients such as various food coloring, spices and oils in food-grade water-soluble film.
technology.prevwork: A study was started in the end of 2018 to explore the possibility of using this material in bags for groceries or dry products sold in bulk (e.g. fruits and vegetables).

technology.name: Bio-plastics
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Bio-materials provide special characteristics to plastics. Innovative advanced materials are continuously in development. Those materials are derived from renewable biomass sources, such as vegetable fats and oils, corn starch, or microbiota. Most of bioplastics are biodegradable, which that under the right conditions the microbes in the environment can break down the material and use it as a food source.
technology.prevwork: A study is available with a list of technologies that can be used. Further study about the most disruptive.

technology.name: Sustainable materials for Textiles
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Promote sustainable materials,  manufacturing processes, and/or waste management. More sustainable materials are based on natural fibres from consciences agriculture or by recycled or recyclable synthetic fibres. More sustainable processes consume less resources such as water and produce less waste.

technology.name: PHA - Waste Based Bioplastic
technology.author: tpc
technology.description: PolyHydroxyAlkanoates (PHA) are polyesters produced in nature by numerous microorganisms, including through bacterial fermentation of sugar or lipids. PHA have active properties and act as a passive barrier to reduce food waste by prolonging food shelf life. PHA can be produced using food industry by-products, such as cheese whey and almond shells, which assure the biodegradability and recyclability, and reduce food waste.
technology.prevwork: YPACK is an EU-funded project with a total duration of 36 months. SONAE MC is partner of YPACK. The project aims to scale up and validate two innovative food packaging solutions based on polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) with active properties and passive barrier to reduce food waste by prolonging food shelf life: a fully renewable flow pack film and fully compostable tray.

partner.description: 100% felted sheep’s wool which is washed in a natural process, scoured then sealed within recyclable industry grade micro-perforated polyethylene wrap. Keeps food contents within various temperature windows, in Chilled, Ambient and Frozen chains, for at least 24 hours.

partner.name: NaturalBlue
partner.author: tpc
partner.description: With a user friendly two-piece design, NaturalBlue is both easy to assemble and effective in maintaining critical temperature thresholds. The recycled denim insulation that powers the performance of NaturalBlue offers many advantages over traditional plastic foam products. Those advanteges are performance, drop protection, damage prevention and odor free.

technology.name: Food life extension additives
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Use biotechnology and/or nanotechnology to produce additives that extend food shelf-life. This technologies avoid the food decomposition by spreading special molecules or using physical treatments. With these actions, the agents that begin food decomposition are contained for a longer period, extending the food's shelf life.
technology.prevwork: A granted project is running that explore this technology.

technology.name: Smart materials for Food security packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Smart materials in food packaging can help to evaluate and preserve the freshness of food. Researchers are working in the development of materials that can protect and preserve food for longer time, such as bacteria-battling nanoparticles that are 50,000 times thinner than human hair.
technology.prevwork: YPACK is an EU-funded project with a total duration of 36 months. SONAE MC is partner of YPACK. The project aims to scale up and validate two innovative food packaging solutions based on polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) with active properties and passive barrier to reduce food waste by prolonging food shelf life: a fully renewable flow pack film and fully compostable tray.

technology.name: Bio-plastics
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Bio-materials provide special characteristics to plastics. Innovative advanced materials are continuously in development. Those materials are derived from renewable biomass sources, such as vegetable fats and oils, corn starch, or microbiota. Most of bioplastics are biodegradable, which that under the right conditions the microbes in the environment can break down the material and use it as a food source.
technology.prevwork: A study is available with a list of technologies that can be used. Further study about the most disruptive.

technology.name: Printed electronics for Disposable smart labels
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Labels with embed sensors and/or displays can help to audit the supply chain. Electrochromic displays are printable on plastic or paper to produce smart labels. These displays use almost no power (no recharging or battery replacement). They are low weight, thin, flexible, transparent, yet robust. Can be combined with sensors (e.g. movement, temperature).
technology.prevwork: A study is available. An experiment to trace the temperature of meat supply chain is being envisaged.

technology.name: Advanced materials for Thermal insulated packaging
technology.author: radar18
technology.description: Use special emergent materials to avoid active refrigeration of food online orders. Specific materials avoid the heat loss from the inside to the outside and can prevent heat transfer to the inside, allowing products to keep the same temperature that they had when packed.
